chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of carpal tunnel syndrome.
chapter.summary: Covers the management and referral of people with carpal tunnel syndrome in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with carpal tunnel syndrome in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer the person to an appropriate specialist (such as a rheumatologist, orthopaedic surgeon, hand surgeon, neurologist or intermediate musculoskeletal assessment and treatment service) depending on local policy, with urgency depending on clinical judgement, where:
    • The diagnosis is unclear.
    • Symptoms are severe or functional ability is reduced.
    • Symptoms recur following carpal tunnel surgery.
    • The patient requests a referral.
    • Conservative management in primary care has failed.
    • A serious condition such as neurological disease, inflammatory joint disease, peripheral limb ischaemia or cervical nerve root entrapment is suspected.
  • If referral is not indicated, manage carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) in primary care by:
    • Optimizing treatment of any underlying condition, such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis or hypothyroidism. See the CKS topics on Osteoarthritis, Rheumatoid arthritis and Hypothyroidism for further information.
    • Advise the person that lifestyle modifications (such as avoidance of repetitive movements or breaks from tasks that precipitate symptoms) may help.
      • If CTS is work-related – advise the person to arrange assessment with their employer to allow adaptation of their workplace (for example provision of different keyboards or reduction of exposure to hand-transmitted vibration) or temporary change of duties.
      • In some cases, people disabled from work related CTS may be eligible for Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit. For more information see the guide from the Department for Work and Pensions DB1 – a guide to Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefits (available at www.dwp.gov.uk).
    • Wrist splinting in a neutral position – this can help with night time symptoms in particular. Splints can be purchased by the person from a pharmacy.
    • Corticosteroid injection – this should only be carried out in primary care if appropriate expertise is available; otherwise, refer to orthopaedics or an intermediate musculoskeletal assessment and treatment service if available locally.
    • Do not prescribe NSAIDS or diuretics to treat CTS.
    • Follow up people treated for carpal tunnel in primary care monthly to ensure that symptoms have resolved — advise the person to return for earlier review if symptoms worsen or new features develop.
    • Provide people with CTS with sources of information and support such as:
      • The British Society for Surgery of the Hand (www.bssh.ac.uk) – information on Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, available as a patient information leaflet.
      • The Royal Orthopaedic Hospital (www.roh.nhs.uk) – information on Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, available as a patient information leaflet.
      • The Royal College of Surgeons (www.rcseng.ac.uk) — information for people undergoing carpal tunnel release surgery available as a patient information leaflet.
      • Arthritis Research UK (www.arthritisresearchuk.org) – information on Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, available as a patient information leaflet.
      • NHS Patient Choices (www.nhs.uk) – an online resource providing information for patients on CTS.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of carpal tunnel syndrome are based on guidelines from the Royal College of Physicians Upper limb disorders: Occupational aspects of management [RCP, 2009], the Washington State Department Work-related carpal tunnel syndrome: Diagnosis and treatment guideline [Washington State Department of Labour and Industries, 2014] and the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) The treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome [AAOS, 2016], the Royal College of Surgeons of England Commissioning guide The treatment of painful tingling fingers [RCS, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [LeBlanc and Cestia, 2011; Middleton and Anakwe, 2014; Dickson et al, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

Referral to secondary care
  • The recommendations on when to refer to secondary care are based on guidelines for healthcare commissioning from the British Society for Surgery of the Hand (BSSH), British Orthopaedic Association (BOA), Royal College of Surgeons of England (RCSEng) [RCS, 2013] and expert opinion in a review article [Middleton and Anakwe, 2014]. 
Conservative management of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS)
  • Lifestyle modification.
    • Lifestyle modifications including the use of ergonomic equipment (such as wrist rests and mouse pads), taking breaks, and alternating job functions are traditionally advocated in the management of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) but evidence supporting their effectiveness is inconsistent [LeBlanc and Cestia, 2011].
    • The AAOS recommend that further workplace intervention studies are needed to confirm efficacy of task modification in improving symptoms and functional deficits in workers with CTS [AAOS, 2016].  
    • The Royal College of Physicians recommend, as a good practice point, that workers with CTS syndrome exposed to hand-transmitted vibration, have their risk from vibration exposure assessed and dependant on medical advice and practicalities, have their exposure reduced [RCP, 2009].
    • The Washington State Department states that where possible, job modification (such as reducing the intensity of manual tasks) may prevent progression and promote recovery from CTS [Washington State Department of Labour and Industries, 2014].
    • CTS is a prescribed disease in workers whose job entails a lot of repeated regular palmar flexion and dorsiflexion movements and in workers who use hand-held powered vibratory tools [Industrial Injuries Advisory Council, 2016].
  • Splints
    • The AAOS found strong evidence to support that immobilization (such as with a brace, splint or orthosis) improves outcomes in CTS [AAOS, 2016].
  • Corticosteroid injection
    • The AAOS found strong evidence in support of use of steroid (methylprednisolone) injection to improve patient-reported outcomes in CTS [AAOS, 2016].
    • The American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine strongly recommends carpal tunnel injection for subacute or chronic CTS [ACOEM, 2011].
  • Non steroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDS) and diuretics
    • The AAOS found moderate evidence supporting no benefit from NSAIDS and diuretics in the treatment of CTS compared to placebo [AAOS, 2016].
Follow up
  • Guidelines for healthcare commissioning from BSSH, BOA and RCSEng suggests that patients with mild CTS should improve within 6 weeks of non-surgical management (with splint and corticosteroid injection) and should be referred if symptoms do not improve or function becomes impaired [RCS, 2013].
  • Expert opinion in a review article [Middleton and Anakwe, 2014] is that benefit from wrist splinting or carpal tunnel injection should be felt within four weeks and that people who do not respond within this time should be reassessed and considered for referral.
